title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds or less, rented without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles for rental purposes. It also defines terms like "defect" and "person" according to specific sections of the United States Code. The term "rental company" refers to a person engaged in renting or leasing 5 or more covered vehicles for rental purposes. The definitions of "vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard" are based on section 30102 of title 49, United States Code. The term "person" is defined in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with defects related to motor vehicle safety or noncompliance with safety standards, unless the issue has been fixed prior to the transaction. The rental company must not rent, lease, or sell a vehicle with safety defects or noncompliance with safety standards unless the issue has been resolved beforehand. Notifications must be received within 5 business days of being mailed during a rental or lease period. During a rental or lease period, a rental company must promptly notify the renter or lessee and any authorized driver of any safety defects or noncompliance with safety standards in the vehicle. The rental company must notify the renter and authorized driver of any safety defects in the vehicle and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the regulations outlined in the Act, effective 60 days after enactment. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act's provisions carry penalties and privileges from the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission's authority remains unaffected by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. State officers must notify the Federal Trade Commission of any civil action. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for injunctive relief. State officers must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating such action. The State must provide a copy of the complaint to the attorney general before filing a civil action. If the attorney general cannot provide notice, the State must do so immediately upon filing the action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in civil actions, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. This section does not prevent State attorneys general from exercising their powers or pursuing violations in State or Federal court. The section allows State attorneys general to proceed in State or Federal court for alleged violations of civil or criminal statutes. No separate suit can be brought if the same violation is already being addressed by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on rental companies selling motor vehicles without standard safety features. The report will include descriptions of buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions. The Administrator must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles without standard safety features, including buying practices, safety implications, and recommendations for regulatory actions. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects before recalls. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Rental companies must be aware of potential defects in vehicles and comply with notifications from the Secretary of Transportation or manufacturers regarding safety issues. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report should include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles, discussion of the effects on consumers, and recommendations from the Administrator. The Administrator must provide a report to Congress within 1 year of the initial report on the sales of vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues. The report should analyze sales frequency, discuss consumer effects, and include any recommendations for legislative or administrative actions. The Administrator must submit a report to Congress on the sales of covered vehicles within a specific period, including analysis, recommendations, and identification of differences in findings. The Administrator's report to Congress includes analysis, recommendations, and identification of differences in findings regarding the effects of the Act on the sales of covered vehicles.
